audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker, who seems to be a professional, introducing himself as a search advocate at Google. He starts talking about the removal report in Search Console and how to use it. He makes it clear that the tool should only be used for temporary removal requests. Music then plays in the background, which is synth-heavy and has an upbeat and happy mood.

The audio begins with a male speaker introducing a video topic about permanent removal of pages from search and referring to links in the description for more details. The speaker clarifies the tool's function is limited to managing search results from the user's own website, directing the listener to further links for information on removing information from Google or the web. The speaker states they are now aligned on what can be removed and proceeds to discuss the removals report in Search Console, clarifying it's the topic of the discussion.

The clip begins with a male speaker introducing the removal report, explaining that it is divided into three sections: temporary removals, outdated content, and safe search filtering requests. He proposes discussing each section to understand their usage. Subsequently, the sound of a liquid being poured into a glass can be heard.

The clip begins with a male speaker explaining that a temporary removal request can be used to take content off Google Search. He mentions that successful requests last about six months, and he speaks in an informative tone. The clip ends with the sound of liquid pouring.

The audio clip starts with a male speaker providing instructions on how to use the removals report in the search console. He describes the temporary removals tab and how to submit a new removal request. He then goes on to explain the two types of requests available: "temporarily remove URL" and "clear cached URL," detailing their respective functions and use cases. He emphasizes the importance of carefully considering requests for entire URL prefixes.

The clip begins with a male speaker explaining the temporary removal section of a report, detailing the information displayed, such as URL, request type, date, and status. He also mentions the possibility to cancel a request. Subsequently, a distinct slurping sound interrupts the speech.

A male speaker with a neutral tone explains Google's outdated content section, removal requests, and two request types: outdated cache removal and outdated page removal. He also discusses the report table. He then recommends viewers check the description for additional information. The clip ends with the sound of someone taking a sip.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing SafeSearch features, explaining how it filters sexually explicit results and is used by families, workplaces, and schools. The speaker has a neutral tone. Following the explanation is a sound of a chewing or crunching nature.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that "permanent removals should not really be part of this video" because it's not required or reported by search console. He then continues with a more conversational tone, explaining that since they're discussing temporary removals so much, a short explanation might be in order.

The clip starts with a single male speaker providing advice on removing content from Google search, emphasizing methods like removing content from the site or blocking access. His tone is informative and professional.

The clip starts with a single male speaker in a neutral, informative tone, stating that redirecting an old page with a 301 response is not enough to remove it from Google search results, and that a robots.txt directive also won't work as a blocking mechanism. He then says, "And that's it, we're done for today".

The audio begins with an authoritative male voice, explaining "how to request to remove specific content on your site from Google search results". He continues describing how to "track these requests", speaking in an informative tone, then announces the topic of the next episode will be how to "check security issues on your website". The speaker encourages listeners to subscribe to the "Google Webmasters YouTube channel", and to "stay tuned". This is followed by light music with a playful mood, possibly electronic in nature. Then comes sounds of rustling and crinkling, suggestive of handling plastic or paper. Someone says "removed", followed by a series of similar utterances of "removed". Another male speaker utters "Ha! Gotcha Junior!" and then breaks into laughter, further punctuated by the sounds of movement and impact, with a suggestion of mischief.
